coredata.dc:title: Large-scale synthesis of low-cost bimetallic polyphthalocyanine for highly stable water oxidation
coredata.dc:creator: Qi, Qianglong
Hu, Jue
Guo, Sitian
Song, Hongchuan
Wang, Shixing
Yao, Yaochun
Le, Thiquynhxuan
Li, Wei
Zhang, Chengxu
Zhang, Libo
coredata.dc:description: Although large-scale synthesis of inexpensive and efficient electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is critical for industrial water splitting, little attention has been paid to that. Here, FeCo-bimetallic polyphthalocyanine (FeCo-PPc) with ultra-low-cost of less than $0.1 per gram and excellent OER electrocatalytic performance has been prepared in kilogram-scale for the first time. The FeCo-PPc catalyst, around 1/5000th times lower the cost of the commercial IrO2, exhibits 24 times higher turnover frequency (0.417 s−1 at 300 mV) and much lower the overpotential (308 mV at 500 mA cm−2) than that of IrO2 (0.0177 s−1 and 588 mV, respectively). Moreover, the FeCo-PPc catalyst shows outstanding long-term stability under an industrial condition (6 M KOH and 85℃) at the high current densities of 100 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2. The excellent OER activity can be attributed to the electron interaction between Fe and Co and the electronegativity of N atoms, which regulate the electron cloud density of neighboring atoms and form active sites to promote the adsorption of reactants. Our work may guide rational design and large-scale synthesis of electrocatalysts that work well at high current densities in industrial conditions.

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Synthesis of FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc and metal-free PPc
Synthesis and structural characterization of M-PPc (M = Fe, Co)
Catalytic activity of FeCo-PPc for OER
Catalytic stability of FeCo-PPc for OER
Structural and morphology characterization of FeCo-PPc after OER stability test

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Graphic procedure of FeCo-PPc synthesis, the photograph and SEM image of the obtained FeCo-PPc catalyst.
Structure characterizations of the prepared catalysts. a) XRD patterns of the FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc and PPc smaples. b) FT-IR spectra of the FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc and PPc smaples.

Morphology characterizations of the prepared catalysts. a) TEM image, b) HRTEM image of FeCo-PPc. c) HAADF-STEM image and corresponding elemental mapping for (d) C, (e) N, (f) Fe, (g) Co of the FeCo-PPc sample.
The high-resolution XPS spectra of a) C 1s of FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc and Co-PPc, b) N 1s of FeCo-PPc, c) Fe 2p of FeCo-PPc and Fe-PPc and d) Co 2p of FeCo-PPc and Co-PPc.

Electrocatalytic properties of the prepared catalysts. a) IR-corrected polarization curves and b) Tafel plots of the FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc, PPc, and IrO2 catalysts in 1 M KOH solution at room temperature. c) Charging current density differences plotted against scan rate and d) Nyquist plots of the FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc, PPc and IrO2 catalysts.

a) TOF plots of the FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc, PPc and IrO2 catalysts at different overpotentials. b) The performance of our FeCo-PPc catalyst compared with those reported MOFs-based OER electrocatalysts in terms of overpotential at 100 mA cm−2 and Tafel slope.

Electrocatalytic stability of the prepared FeCo-PPc and commercial IrO2 catalysts. a) Catalytic stability testing at the constant current density of 100 mA cm−2 and the anodic polarization curves of the b) FeCo-PPc and c) IrO2 in 1 M KOH at room temperature. d) Overpotential of FeCo-PPc and IrO2 at different current densities before and after stability tests (24 h at 100 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH).

Electrocatalytic stability of the prepared FeCo-PPc catalyst in industrial condition. a) Catalytic stability testing of FeCo-PPc under industry operating conditions of 6 M KOH and 85 ℃ at 100 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2. b) Polarization curves before and after stability test of FeCo-PPc at 6 M KOH and 85℃.

The chemical and structural characterizations of the FeCo-PPc catalyst after OER stability test in 1 M KOH at 100 mA cm−2 for 24 h. a) XRD pattern of FeCo-PPc after stability test at a constant current density of 100 mA cm−2. The high-resolution XPS spectra of (b) Fe 2p, (c) Co 2p of FeCo-PPc after stability tests at a constant current density of 100 mA cm−2.

The morphology characterizations of the FeCo-PPc catalyst after OER stability test at 100 mA cm−2 for 24 h. a) SEM image, b) TEM image, and (c) HRTEM image of the FeCo-PPc catalyst after catalytic stability testing by chronopotentiometry responses (E-t) recorded at the current densities of 100 mA cm−2 for more than 24 h. d-h) HAADF-STEM image and the corresponding mapping of C, O, Fe, Co elements.

head.ce:title: Large-scale synthesis of low-cost bimetallic polyphthalocyanine for highly stable water oxidation

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: FeCo-bimetallic polyphthalocyanine (FeCo-PPc) with ultra-low cost and excellent oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalytic performance has been prepared in kilogram-scale. The FeCo-PPc shows excellent long-term stability under an industrial hydrogen production condition (6 M KOH and 85℃).

Although large-scale synthesis of inexpensive and efficient electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is critical for industrial water splitting, little attention has been paid to that. Here, FeCo-bimetallic polyphthalocyanine (FeCo-PPc) with ultra-low-cost of less than $0.1 per gram and excellent OER electrocatalytic performance has been prepared in kilogram-scale for the first time. The FeCo-PPc catalyst, around 1/5000th times lower the cost of the commercial IrO2, exhibits 24 times higher turnover frequency (0.417 s−1 at 300 mV) and much lower the overpotential (308 mV at 500 mA cm−2) than that of IrO2 (0.0177 s−1 and 588 mV, respectively). Moreover, the FeCo-PPc catalyst shows outstanding long-term stability under an industrial condition (6 M KOH and 85℃) at the high current densities of 100 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2. The excellent OER activity can be attributed to the electron interaction between Fe and Co and the electronegativity of N atoms, which regulate the electron cloud density of neighboring atoms and form active sites to promote the adsorption of reactants. Our work may guide rational design and large-scale synthesis of electrocatalysts that work well at high current densities in industrial conditions.

ce:section.ce:para: Hydrogen, as one of the cleanest fuels, plays a central role in realizing our goal of carbon neutrality [1,2]. Electrochemical splitting of water has been considered to be the highly desirable alternative pathway to produce hydrogen [3–5]. However, the realization of efficient water splitting is greatly impeded by the sluggish four electron-transferred oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Currently, noble-metal oxides such as IrO2 and RuO2 have been proved to be the most effective OER electrocatalysts, but their high cost (about $500 per gram for IrO2 and $140 per gram for RuO2), limited resources, and poor stability greatly restrict their commercial application [6–9]. Therefore, large-scale synthesizing OER catalysts with low-cost and high performance is the vital step to accelerate the industrialization of water splitting.

Recently, great efforts have been made to develop efficient non-noble metal-based catalysts such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [10–12], high-entropy alloys (HEAs) [13,14], layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [1,15,16], covalent-organic frameworks (COFs) [17], metal-covalent organic frameworks (MCOFs) [18], transition metal sulfide [19–21], and transition metal carbides (TMCs) [22,23]. Among many state-of-the-art OER catalysts, MOFs have attracted extensive attention owing to their tunable structure, large specific surface area, and controllable electric properties [24]. At present, the effective strategies for developing OER catalysts mainly focus on improving MOFs intrinsic activity and exposing a large number of active sites. Metal polyphthalocyanine (M-PPc) has the conjugated aromatic structure consisting of transition metal center with adjustable oxidation state and a macrocyclic ligand framework [25]. Theoretical studies have shown that the strong electronegativity of nitrogen atoms in the phthalocyanine ring could regulate the electron cloud density of the adjacent atoms and form the metal-nitrogen active site to promote the adsorption of reactants [26]. Recently, Wang et al. prepared the N-doped carbon-supported Ni-Fe nanoparticles using NiFe-PPc as precursor for water splitting, showing good electrocatalytic activities [27]. Li et al. prepared the N-doped porous carbon with atomically dispersed Fe-N4 catalytic site using FeZn-PPc as a precursor and showed good OER, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activities [26]. Bimetal N-doped porous graphitic carbon networks (M-NC) were prepared via pyrolysis using M-PPc as the precursor and showed good electrocatalytic ORR activities [28]. Wang et al. used Co-PPC as the precursor to prepare a uniform ultra-thin conjugated aromatic network structure by ball milling, showing good ORR activity [29]. In addition, Fe-PPc was sintered at 400 ℃ under Ar flow to obtain a carbon-based catalyst with good ORR activity [30]. Inorganic-organic hybridization catalysts with high efficiency for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction was obtained by Co-PPc sheathed carbon nanotubes [25]. Most reports focus on using M-PPc as template or precursor to create efficient electrocatalysts. However, few M-PPc materials were directly employed for oxygen evolution electrocatalysis. Herein, FeCo-bimetallic polyphthalocyanine (FeCo-PPc) with ultra-low cost of $0.1 (CNY 0.6) per gram has been synthesized in kilogram-scale and directly performed in OER electrocatalysis for the first time. The synthesized FeCo-PPc catalyst shows particularly high OER activity with the overpotentials of 232 mV and 308 mV at the current density of 20 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH electrolyte, respectively, and promising long-term stability even at high current densities under the industrial hydrogen production conditions of 6 M KOH and 85 ℃.

Pyromellitic dianhydride (PMDA), NH4Cl, Ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (H24Mo7N6O24·4H2O), CoCl2·6H2O, urea, acetone, FeCl3·6H2O, and ethanol were bought from Aladdin Reagent. IrO2 was bought from sigma-Aldrich. Ultrapure deionized water (18.2 MΩ cm−1) was used in all experiments. All of the above chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. Commercial nickel foams (NF, nickel content: 99.8 %) were purchased from Taiyuan Liyuan Lithium Battery Technology Co. Ltd. and cut into small pieces having a geometric area of 1 cm × 3 cm. NF was first ultrasonicated in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Sigma-Aldrich) for 1 h, and then washed with deionized water alternately three-time, and dried at room temperature.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc and metal-free PPc
ce:section.ce:para: A prototypical FeCo-PPc material was synthesized by a combination of literature methods [28,29]. Firstly, PMDA (3.4 mol), urea (20 mol), NH4Cl (6 mol), H24Mo7N6O24·4H2O (0.7 mmol), FeCl3·6H2O (0.74 mol) and CoCl2·6H2O (0.74 mol) were mixed and fully ground. The mixture heated in a muffle furnace at a heating temperature of 3℃ min−1 at 220℃ for 3 h into a crucible. Then, after cooling to room temperature, the product was washed with deionized water and organic solvent (acetone and ethanol) alternately three-time before drying for 12 h at 60℃.

The preparation process of Fe-PPc and Co-PPc is similar to that of FeCo-PPc, except that the molar ratio of FeCl3·6H2O and CoCl2·6H2O is different at the beginning. The molar ratio of FeCl3·6H2O vs. CoCl2·6H2O was controlled at 1:0, 0:1 with the resulting products denoted as Fe-PPc and Co-PPc, respectively. In addition, metal-free PPc was prepared without adding metal chloride.

PMDA (1.05 g), urea (2.05 g), NH4Cl (0.5 g), and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (0.00225 g), FeCl3·6H2O (0.30 g) and CoCl2·6H2O (0.264 g) were mixed and fully ground. The mixture heated in a muffle furnace at a heating temperature of 3 ℃ min−1 at 220℃ for 3 h into a crucible. Then, after cooling to room temperature, the product was washed with deionized water and organic solvent (acetone and ethanol) alternately three-time before drying for 12 h at 60℃.

Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was procured by using Rigaku D/Max-2200 under Cu Ka radiation at 40 kV, 40 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was acquired with PHI 5500 XPS Spectrometer with a resolution of 0.3−0.5 eV from a monochromated aluminum anode X-ray source with Mo Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). All XPS spectra were calibrated using the C 1s peak of carbon present at 284.80 eV. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was performed by a Nona-Nano SEM450 at the accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy-energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (HAADF-STEM-EDX) were characterized on Tecnai G2 TF30 operating at 300 kV. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were conducted on a Thermo Electron NEXUS 670 FT-IR spectrometer. The contents of Fe and Co were obtained by inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) conducted on a PE Avio 200 instrument. ICP mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was measured on an iCAP Qc spectrometer at 1150 W.

Electrochemical measurements were performed with a CHI760E workstation (CH Instruments, Inc.) using a standard three-electrode electrochemical cell with Pt sheet and Hg/HgO as the counter electrode and the reference electrode, respectively. The catalyst ink for OER tests was prepared as following: 10 mg of catalysts is transfer into a mixed solution of deionized water (200 μL) and 0.5 % Nafion ethanol solution (300 μL), and then ultrasonicated for 30 min to obtain a homogeneous solution. The catalysts ink (25 μL) is then loaded on NF (0.5 cm2) by drop coating to form the electrode, and dried slowly at room temperature. The final mass loading of the catalysts on electrode is around 1 mg cm−2. The IrO2 for OER tests was prepared as following: 4 mg of IrO2 is transfer into a mixed solution of 1.5 mL of deionized water, 0.5 mL of 0.5 % Nafion water solution, 2 mL of isopropanol, and then ultrasonicated for half-hour. 50 μL of the IrO2 ink was loaded on a clean NF electrode (0.5 cm2) by drop coating to form the electrode. The final mass loading of the IrO2 on electrode is around 0.1 mg cm−2.

For the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) calibration, the potential difference between Hg/HgO and RHE was measured in a H2-saturated 1 M KOH solution. Cyclic voltammograms (CV) cures were taken several cycles to bubble away the surface contaminates and at the same time stabilize the catalysts. The polarization curves were obtained with a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 in O2-saturated electrolyte. Double-layer capacitance (C dl) was estimated by the CV cures at various scan rates (10∼50 mV) in the potential region of 0.1∼0.2 V vs. RHE. All the polarization curves were iR-corrected, except as otherwise noted. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is recorded at an applied potential of 1.53 V vs. RHE from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz.

Chronopotentiometry (CP) responses curve was performed under a high constant current density of 100 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH using carbon rod as the counter electrode at room temperature. Chronopotentiometry tests under industry operating conditions were conducted at 85 ℃ under high current densities of 100 and 500 mA cm−2 with 6.0 M KOH as electrolyte using carbon rod as the counter electrode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis and structural characterization of M-PPc (M = Fe, Co)
ce:section.ce:para: The metal polyphthalocyanine (M-PPc, M = Fe, Co) were prepared in muffle furnace by one-step solid-phase method [27–29]. In a typical process, pyromellitic dianhydride (PMDA), urea, ammonium chloride, ammonium molybdate and metal chloride were mixed and ground adequately. Subsequently, the mixture was heated in a muffle furnace at 220 ℃ for 3 h (Fig. 1). In this process, the phthalocyanine monomer is converted to a polymer via coupling with the functional groups of organic ligand PMDA. Kilogram-scale synthesis of FeCo-PPc could be realized via this solid-phase strategy by adding FeCl3·6H2O and CoCl2·6H2O, with the cost about $0.1 per gram. Approximately, a kilogram-scale product (about 1008.5 g) was obtained, and the yield was as high as 90.1 %. Fe-PPc, Co-PPc and metal-free polyphthalocyanine (PPc) were synthesized in the same synthesis process when added FeCl3·6H2O, CoCl2·6H2O and no metal chloride in the synthesis process, respectively (Table S1). FeCo-PPc was also prepared in small-scale (labeled SS-FeCo-PPc) under the same synthesis condition for comparison. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc and PPc samples possess the same X-ray diffractograms (XRD) patterns with PPc based materials shown in the literatures, indicating the successful synthesis of the polyphthalocyanine framework [28,31,32]. The XRD patterns of the obtained samples can be deconvoluted into two π–π stacked crystal forms: the evenly aligned Alpha form of metal polyphthalocyanine (α-M-PPc) which exhibits a P4/MMM space group and unit cell with the parameters a = b = 10.578823 Å, c = 3.044001 Å, α = β = γ = 90 °, and the staggered Beta form of metal polyphthalocyanine (β-M-PPc) which shows an I4/MMM space group and tetragonal unit cell with the parameters a = b = 10.97987 Å, c = 5.189102 Å, α = β = γ = 90 ° (Fig. S1). The main diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 17.3˚, 18.4˚, 18.9˚, 25.7˚, 29.5˚, and 30.4˚ in all of the samples are assigned to the (200), (001), (101) planes of β-M-PPc, (310), (001), and (101) planes of α-M-PPc, respectively. The functional group and molecular structure of metal polyphthalocyanine were analyzed by FT-IR. Fig. 2 b shows the FT-IR spectra for a typical PPc structure with dominant signals of the phthalocyanine frameworks at 1699, 1465 and 1371 cm–1, the stretching vibration of CN at 1308 and 1150 cm–1, the carbon-carbon double bond (CC) aromatic stretching at 1699 cm–1 [27,29,30,33], the wagging and torsional vibrations of the CH groups at 638−764 cm–1, and the isoindole ring stretching vibrations at 1063−1465 cm–1 [34]. New signal at 945 cm–1 for FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc samples, which is disappeared for PPc, is related to the vibration of the metal-ligand bond (MN), suggesting the successful coordination of metal–N in the M-PPc matrix [27,29,33]. As shown in Fig. S2−3, the XRD and FT-IR signals of FeCo-PPc are the same to those of the small-scale prepared FeCo-PPc (SS-FeCo-PPc), indicating the same chemical structure of FeCo-PPc preparing in large-scale and small-scale.

Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) showed a massive morphology of monometallic and bimetallic polyphthalocyanine (Figs. 1 and S4). The FESEM image shows that the FeCo-PPc has a layer-stacked structure. The surface of FeCo-PPc is rougher than that of Fe-PPc and Co-PPc, which is beneficial the exposure of more active sites [15]. This layer-stacked structure of FeCo-PPc can also be found in the TEM images (Figs. 3
a and S5). The highly ordered lattice planes in the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of FeCo-PPc are clearly seen in Fig. 3b, indicating a good crystallinity. Lattice fringes with the distances of 0.265 nm corresponded to the (410) facet of the staggered Alpha form of FeCo polyphthalocyanine [32]. The component information was further obtained by HAADF-STEM-EDX. It can be known from Fig. 3 c that the C, N, Fe, and Co (Fig. 3 d–g) elements are spread over the whole region of FeCo-PPc. Besides, according to the ICP-OES analysis, it was determined that the atomic ratio of Fe/Co is about 1:1.22, which is consistent with the feeding ratio of Fe and Co salts (1:1) (Table S2).

The chemical composition and states of the catalyst were further determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS survey spectra confirmed the presence of nonmetals (C, N, O), and metals (Fe, Co) in the FeCo-PPc, FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc and Co-PPc samples (Fig. S6 and Table S3). In the C 1s spectra (Fig. 4 a), the dominant peak at 284.70 eV corresponds to CC/CC carbon species, and the relatively smaller peaks at 286.12 eV and 288.09 eV are assigned to CN and CO, respectively. [35–37] In the high-resolution XPS N 1s spectra of FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc, Co-PPc samples (Figs. 4 b and S7), the peaks of 400.80 eV, 399.41 eV and 398.73 eV can be attributed to the MN bonds (MCo, Fe), nitrogen atom linking the isoindole rings (N β ) and nitrogen atoms adjacent to the central metal atom (N α ), respectively, which also confirm the metal-nitrogen coordination framework structure of the metal phthalocyanine [24,32,38]. In the as-prepared FeCo-PPc, the high-resolution XPS Fe 2p spectrum displays two major peaks of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 at 711.80 and 725.12 eV, respectively, which can be deconvoluted into two doublets at 710.91 eV and 725.07 eV for Fe2+ and 713.24 eV and 727.60 eV for Fe3+ (Figs. 4 c and S8a). [35] Compared with Fe-PPc, the electron binding energies of Fe 2P3/2 and 2P1/2 for FeCo-PPc shift to higher energies (ΔE = 0.74 eV), indicating that the chemical environment changes with the increase of Co central electron density, which is conducive to the improvement of OER activity. [39,40] The high-resolution Co 2p spectrum of FeCo-PPc (Figs. 4 d and S8b) is deconvoluted to two doublets which are assigned to Co2+ (781.23 eV, 796.45 eV) and Co3+ (779.13 eV, 794.60 eV). Compared with Co-PPc (Co2+/Co3+ ≈ 3.83/1), the content of Co3+ in FeCo-PPc (Co2+/Co3+ ≈ 4.3/1) is reduced [41,42]. The electron binding energies of both Fe and Co 2p spectra shift to a higher energy are observed in bimetallic FeCo-PPc compared with monometallic Fe-PPc and Co-PPc samples, which indicates a strong electron interaction between Co and Fe in FeCo-PPc [43]. In addition, compared with the XPS fitting results of FeCo-PPc and SS-FeCo-PPc, the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ is close to 4.3/1, while the ratio of Fe3+/Fe2+ is 1.2/1 and 1/1.1, respectively (Fig. S9). This further confirms the same chemical structure between the catalysts produced in large-scale and small-scale.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Catalytic activity of FeCo-PPc for OER
ce:section.ce:para: The electrocatalytic OER performances of FeCo-PPc, Fe-PPc and Co-PPc samples were studied in a three-electrode system in O2-saturated 1 M KOH solution at room temperature. According to the polarization curves shown in Fig. 5 a, the bimetallic FeCo-PPc catalyst exhibits a lowest overpotential of 232 mV at a current density of 20 mA cm−2, comparing to that of the Fe-PPc (346 mV), Co-PPc (419 mV), PPc (434 mV) and IrO2 (365 mV) catalysts (Table S4). Impressively, the obtained FeCo-PPc catalyst achieves ultra-low overpotential of 308 mV at high current density of 500 mA cm−2, which is much better than that of commercial IrO2 (588 mV). SS-FeCo-PPc prepared by small-scale synthesis shows the similar OER performance with FeCo-PPc catalyst (Fig. S10). The outstanding OER activity of FeCo-PPc can be attributed to the strong electron interaction between Co and Fe and the electronegativity of the N atoms, which regulate the electron cloud density of adjacent atoms and form the active site to promote the adsorption of the reactants [24,26,27]. The Tafel slope of the FeCo-PPc (42.86 mV dec–1) is lower than that of Fe-PPc (55.7 mV dec–1), IrO2 (82.6 mV dec–1), Co-PPc (83.26 mV dec–1), and PPc (100.15 mV dec–1) (Fig. 5b), demonstrating a faster OER kinetics of the FeCo-PPc. It is known that the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the electrocatalyst is proportional to the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl), which can be evaluated by measuring the scan-rate-dependent CV in the non-Faraday region [44]. The Cdl value can be expressed by the equation △j = (j a–j c)/2 at 1.07 V vs. RHE and the curves of different scanning rates (Fig. S11) [20,44]. The measured Cdl value of FeCo-PPc is 52.33 mF cm–2, which is larger than that of the other samples suggesting more exposed surface reactive sites, and as a result much better OER activity of FeCo-PPc (Fig. 5 c and Table S4). To further illustrate the electrode reaction kinetics during the catalytic OER process, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed. As shown in Fig. 5 d the Nyquist plots reveal that FeCo-PPc has a low charge transfer resistance (Rct) of about 0.901 Ω at the overpotential of 300 mV (at 1.53 V vs. RHE) in 1 M KOH, which is much smaller than that Fe-PPc, Co-PPc, PPc and IrO2 catalysts, indicating a much faster charge transfer on the FeCo-PPc surface in the electrochemical reaction process. These results firmly demonstrated the excellent activity of FeCo-PPc for OER. Impressively, as shown in Fig. 6 a, the FeCo-PPc catalyst, around 1/5000th times lower the cost of the commercial IrO2 displays an ultrahigh turnover frequency (TOF) of 0.417 s−1 at the overpotential of 300 mV in alkaline medium, which is about 24 times higher than that of commercial IrO2 (0.0177 s−1) [45]. In addition, the overpotential required for maintaining the OER current density of 100 mA cm−2 and Tafel slopes for the most efficient relevant catalysts are compiled in Fig. 6 b and Table S5. It is worth note that the OER performance of FeCo-PPc is superior or at least comparable to that of most active MOFs derived OER catalysts in alkaline medium (Table S5).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Catalytic stability of FeCo-PPc for OER
ce:section.ce:para:
For a practical electrocatalyst, it is significant to maintain good durability over long-term use, especially at high current densities. The Chronopotentiometry responses (E-t) curve in Fig. 7
a demonstrates that FeCo-PPc catalyst possesses good durability with negligible potential change after OER test for 24 h at a current density of 100 mA cm−2. The overpotential after the stability test increased only 3 mV at the current density of 100 mA cm−2, compared with that before the stability test (Fig. 7 b). Moreover, FeCo-PPc has higher OER activity and long-term stability compared with IrO2 (Fig. 7 cd). The measured Cdl value of FeCo-PPc after the stability test is 46.3 mF cm–2, indicating that the catalyst maintains a large electrochemically active surface area after the stability test (Fig. S12). The Nyquist plots reveal that there is no change of the charge transfer ability for FeCo-PPc catalyst before and after long-term durability test (Fig. S13-14). More importantly, one can see that the potential for keeping the current density of 100 mA cm−2 for 100 h in 1 M KOH electrolyte showed negligible increase, demonstrating the good long-term stability of the FeCo-PPc catalyst toward OER (Fig. S15). Furthermore, FeCo-PPc also exhibited excellent stability even under the industrial conditions (6 M KOH and 85 ℃). The potential maintained in a horizontal trend while successively keeping the current density at 100 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2 for more than 12 h and 9 h, respectively (Figs. 8
a and S16). As the polarization curves shown in Fig. 8b, the overpotential increased only 4 mV at 500 mA cm−2 after the long-term stability test in the harsh industrial conditions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structural and morphology characterization of FeCo-PPc after OER stability test
ce:section.ce:para:
FESEM, XRD, TEM, XPS, and ICP-MS were used to characterize the morphology and structure of the FeCo-PPc catalyst after stability test at a 100 mA cm−2 for 24 h. According to the XRD pattern, the diffraction peak of FeCo-PPc disappeared. New peaks appear which are matched well with γ-CoOOH (PDF card no. 73–1213), FeCoOOH (PDF card no. 14-0558), FeO (PDF card no. 49-1447), Fe(OH)3 (PDF card no. 22-0346), Co2O3 (PDF card no. 20-0770), and γ-FeOOH (PDF card no. 44-1415), suggesting a complete phase transition (Fig. 9 a). The high-resolution XPS survey spectrum after stability test for FeCo-PPc reveals the presence of C (51.2 at%), O (33.2 at%), N (11.6 at%), Fe (2.9 at%), and Co (1.2 at%), suggesting a remarkable increase of O content in FeCo-PPc during the OER process (Table S2). Besides, high-resolution XPS spectra for Fe 2p and Co 2p show deconvoluted peaks for Fe3+ (712.34 eV and 726.57 eV), Fe2+ (710.66 eV and 724.80 eV), Co3+ (779.33 eV and 795.23 eV) and Co2+ (781.33 eV and 796.54 eV), respectively (Fig. 9 b-c). The fitting results show that the ratio of Fe3+/Fe2+ (about 1/1) and the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ (about 1/2.5) for FeCo-PPc after durability test are increased comparing to those of FeCo-PPc before durability test (1.2/1 and 1/4.3, respectively), confirming the oxidation of catalyst during OER process. Fitting data of the high-resolution C1 s and N1 s in Fig. S17 shows a reduction in C–N content after the stability test for FeCo-PPc, which is consistent with the XRD results. Furthermore, based on the ICP-MS results, the Fe and Co contents of FeCo-PPc after the stability test are 0.5041 % and 0.9796 %, respectively (Table S2). The SEM images after the stability test in Figs. 10
a and S18a-d show that the catalyst still has layered overlay texture. A TEM image exhibits the blocky structure feature without any obvious particles (Fig. 10b). The lattice fringes of 0.23 nm and 0.283 nm are corresponded to the (012) planes of γ-CoOOH and (002) facet of Co2O3, respectively (Fig. 10c). The component information was further obtained by HAADF-STEM-EDX. It can be known from Fig. 10 d that the C, O, Fe, and Co (Fig. 10 e-h) elements are spread over the whole region for the FeCo-PPc catalyst after the stability test. The long-term stability is largely controlled by the active species and overall structure after the surface reconstruction [46,47]. It has been found that many catalysts reconstituted into oxides and hydroxyl oxides, which also possessed excellent OER activity [46,48–50]. This may be the reason for the outstanding stability of the FeCo-PPc catalyst for OER electrocatalysis. Moreover, the chemical compositions of FeCo-PPc after catalytic stability test of FeCo-PPc under industry operating conditions (6 M KOH and 85℃ at 100 mA cm−2) was also investigated. The high-resolution XPS survey spectrum of FeCo-PPc reveals the presence of C (56.2 at%), O (24.3 at%), N (17.3 at%), Fe (0.9 at%), and Co (1.4 at%), indicating high stability even under industrial conditions (Table S3). The high-resolution XPS spectra for Fe 2p and Co 2p show deconvoluted peaks for Fe3+ (712.61 eV and 727.57 eV), Fe2+ (710.84 eV and 725.40 eV), Co3+ (779.42 eV and 794.75 eV) and Co2+ (781.41 eV and 796.65 eV), respectively (Fig. S19). The fitting results show that the ratio of Fe3+/Fe2+ (about 1/1.1) and Co3+/Co2+ (about 1/2.7) for FeCo-PPc after durability test under industrial conditions (6 M KOH) are approximately consistent with FeCo-PPc after durability test in 1 M KOH solution (1/1 and 1/2.5, respectively), confirming the catalyst remains stable even in 6 M KOH electrolyte.

In summary, we synthesized efficient OER electrocatalyst in kilogram-scale by a simple one-step solid-phase method. The obtained FeCo-PPc catalyst with ultra-low cost of $0.1 (CNY 0.6) per gram possesses outstanding OER electrocatalytic activity, including a small overpotential (308 mV at 500 mA cm−2), a small Tafel slope (42.86 mV dec–1), a small charge transfer resistance (0.9 Ω) at the overpotential of 300 mV, due to the strong electron interaction between Co and Fe and the electronegativity of the N atoms. Impressively, the FeCo-PPc catalyst exhibits superexcellent long-term durability at high current densities of 100 mA cm−2 for 100 h in 1 M KOH solution and at 100 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2 even in industrial conditions (6 M KOH and 85℃), demonstrating tremendous potential for commercial applications. This work will open up a unique way for the large-scale fabrication of highly efficient and low-cost OER catalysts for industrial water oxidation.

Qianglong Qi: Data curation, Original draft preparation, Writing-Reviewing. Jue Hu: Conceptualization, Methodology, Writing-Reviewing and Editing. Sitian Guo: Data curation, Original draft preparation. Hongchuan Song: Writing. Shixing Wang: Visualization. Yaochun Yao: Investigation, Supervision. Thiquynhxuan Le: Original draft preparation. Wei Li: Writing-Reviewing. Chengxu Zhang: Methodology, Writing-Reviewing and Editing. Libo Zhang: Conceptualization, Writing-Reviewing and Editing.
